Bentinck Street in the neighbourhood of Golden Square, Soho, runs out of Berwick Street. It was at one time the location of the studio of the engraver John Keyse Sherwin, a pupil of the Italian-born engraver Francesco Bartolozzi. See Edward Walford, 'Golden Street and neighbourhood', in Old and New London: Volume 4 (London, 1878), pp. 235–246. British History Online here [accessed 28 June 2019].

North End, a hamlet of Fulham, near Hammersmith. It was the location of a house known as 'Cambridge Lodge', home to the engraver Francesco Bartolozzi from 1777. See Edward Walford, 'Fulham: Walham Green and North End', in Old and New London: Volume 6 (London, 1878), pp. 521–528, British History Online, here [accessed 28 June 2019]. Note that the date of Bartolozzi's arrival at North End is given as 1780 in Selwyn Brinton, Bartolozzi and his pupils in England: with an abridged list of his more important prints in line and stipple (New York: F. A. Stokes, 1903), p. 52.

A village in Shropshire. A banqueting house at Eyton (c. 1607) is one of the few remains of the work carried out under Sir Francis Newport on a house at Eyton, most of which was complete by 1595, but later destroyed by fire. See Hist P s.n. Francis Newport II (c. 1555–1623), of High Ercall, Salop; here [accessed 26 June 2019].

placeName.note: Aberdeen Castle was razed in the early sixteenth century, so it is likely that very little remained to be seen by eighteenth-century travellers.
Ben Arthur, or The Cobbler, is a distinctive three-headed peak in a group of mountains known as the Arrochar Alps.

Patagonia is a region in southern area of South America, shared by Argentina and Chile. A ship called the 'Mimosa' sailed from Liverpool in 1865, which carried approximately 150 Welsh passengers, it was recorded in the early 21st century that approximately 50,000 of Patagonians were of Welsh descent. The Welsh colony in Patagonia is known as 'Y Wladfa'.

Snowdonia is a mountainous region in north-west Wales and now a national park. Within Snowdonia is Snowdon, which is the highest peak in Wales, 1085m and also the highest peak in the UK outside Scotland.

Town on the north Wales coast in Conwy County Borough.

Plas y Ward, Llanynys, Denbighshire. The only reference to it in A tour in Wales appears in connection with Edward Thelwal (sic), d. 1591, who became the third husband of Katheryn of Berain. Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), II, p. 27. A watercolour drawing by Moses Griffith is included in Pennant's extra-illustrated A Journey to Snowdon (1781; limited large paper edn., 1786), here, p. 59.

82-mile long earthwork boundary dyke, running along the Wales-England border, probably built by the Mercian king Offa in the late eighth century. See here [accessed 25 June 2019].
The gap in the dyke', named on account of a gap in Offa's Dyke, north-east of Coedpoeth.
North-west of Wrexham.

North of Coedpoeth near Wrexham, Denbighshire. The mines were worked for lead as early as the late thirteenth century, with production greatly increasing during the latter part of the eighteenth century. For the New Minera shaft, which operated from 1889 until the early twentieth century, see here [accessed 2 July 2019].

placeName.addName: Mathravael; Kingdom of Mathrafal or Powys Land; Powys Land; all Powys
placeName.note: The main court of Powys, Mathrafal gave its name to the descendants of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn. Davies, A History of Wales, p. 116; Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 607.

placeName.addName: Powysfadoc; Powys Fadoc; Powys Vadoc; lower Powys
placeName.note: The lordship of Powys Fadog, named after Madog ap Gruffudd (d. 1236), was created on the death of his grandfather, Madog ap Maredudd, in 1160. It included Maelor Gymraeg, Maelor Saesneg, Iâl, Edeirnion, Nanheudwy, Cynllaith and a part of Mochnant. Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 746. See also House of Powys Fadog.
A county in north-east Wales.

On the use of the name 'Bromfield' for Maelor Saesneg as well as Maelor Gymraeg, see the reference to 'that Bromfield which lay in Flintshire, and was from that time called Maelor Saesneg' in Davies, A display of herauldry, p. 19.
Village, community and parish in north Powys, famed for its waterfall, 'Pistyll Rhaeadr'.
In the old county of Denbighshire, Holt Castle was built between 1282 and 1311, and demolished during the second half of the seventeenth century. See here [accessed 14 June 2019].

placeName.addName: NWales; N: wales; N-Wales; NW; Northwales
Gwynedh or North-Wales; North Wales; Gwyned. [sic]
placeName.note: The kingdom and principality of Gwynedd, generally the most powerful Welsh political entity during the Middle Ages and up to the time of the Edwardian conquest.

Created through the union of Dyfed and Seisyllwg in 920, with the later addition of Brycheiniog, Deheubarth was the last of the four main Welsh kingdoms to develop and was consequently less powerful than its rivals, Gwynedd, Powys and Glamorgan. Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 286.
Now a Welsh county which borders with England, Powys was a medieval kingdom, at one time divided into Powys Fadog to the north and Powys Wenwynwyn to the south.
Powys Wenwynwyn was the name for the southern part of the kingdom of Powys, which came under the rule of Owain Cyfeiliog following the death of Madog ap Maredudd in 1160. Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 745.
River which has its source at Plynlimon, mid Wales, before flowing down the Wales-England border and then out into the Bristol Channel.

A marcher lordship in north-east Wales created following the Edwardian conquest, Chirkland continued to be ruled separately until legislation for the unification of Wales with England came to force in 1535 and 1542.
Cefn y Wern, Chirk, Denbighshire, a property in the ownership of the Edwards family by the middle of the sixteenth century. See here [accessed 6 November 2019].

Plas Newydd (or New Hall) in the historical marcher lordship of Chirkland was among the residences of the Edwards family. See DWB s.n. Edwards or Edwardes family, of Chirkland, Denbighshire, Pembrokeshire, and Kensington; and for the lineage of a fifteenth-century member of the family, here [accessed 6 November 2019].
A Flintshire mansion, parts of which were constructed in the early seventeenth century. See here [accessed 6 November 2019].

Late thirteenth-century castle built during the conquest of Wales. From the sixteenth century, it was used as a stately home and seat of the Myddelton family. See here and here [both accessed 6 November 2019].

The earliest church at Gresford, dating to the late fourteenth century, was replaced in the late fifteenth century by a building constructed from carboniferous sandstone. The interior was decorated with carved heads, flowers and animals, and contained statues (among them one of the Virgin, now eroded, and of a figure identified, probably erroneously, as Henry VII). See here [accessed 6 June 2019].
Village on the main coaching road (now A5) between Corwen and Llangollen. The Welsh rebel leader Owain Glyndwr traditionally lived nearby (see Owain Glyndwr's Mount),
A commot in Powys.
Oswestry, Shropshire, is located near the Welsh border.

Dating from the early seventeenth century, Llannerch Hall, Trefnant, Denbighshire, was famous for its gardens, created at the end of the same century. See here and here [both accessed 6 November 2019].

Plas Coch, Llanychan, Denbighshire, was built for Eubule Thelwall (1562–1630), who bequeathed it to his nephew John. DWB s.n. Thelwall family, Plas y Ward, Batharfan, Plas Coch and Llanbedr, Denbighshire.
Cheshire village and parish on the Flintshire side of the river Dee.
A Flintshire village, close to the Welsh/English border. Hope (Welsh: Yr Hob) was a commote within the Kingdom of Powys during the Middle Ages.
The mansion of Rhual in Flintshire was built in 1634. See here [accessed 6 November 2019].

Fifteenth-century mansion near the Denbighshire coast, remodelled in the nineteenth century; see here [accessed 6 November 2019]. For a contemporary image of the house, taken from Pennant’s extra-illustrated A tour in Wales, see here, p. 341; or here [both accessed 6 November 2019].

Hampshire.

A commot of Powys Fadog. It became part of the lordship of Chirk upon the Edwardian conquest of 1284, but the eastern part was retained by the a branch of the Powys Fadog family, from whom it descended to Owain Glyndwr. Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 241.

placeName.addName: Kin[...]r Edge; Kinvar edge; Ken-vawr in British a great bank; the latter Camp; Kinvar
placeName.note: On the border between Staffordshire and Worcestershire, Kinver Edge is the location of a hillfort from the Iron Age or, possibly, the earlier Late Bronze Age. See here [accessed 11 April 2019].

placeName.addName: parish of Kidderminster; Parish of Kiderminster; Parish of Kederminster
great Whitley; parish of Great Whitley
placeName.note: In northwest Worcestershire.
Witley Court in Great Witley, Worcestershire, came into the ownership of the Foley family after the seventeenth-century civil wars. See here [accessed 25 March 2019].
For the hillfort on Woodbury Hill in the parish of Great Witley, Worcestershire, see here [accessed 11 April 2019].
Worcestershire. Home of Pennant's friend, Treadway Russell Nash.
The 'marches' are the areas on the border between England and Wales in which Norman lords exercised a degree of autonomy from the king of England during the Middle Ages.
In north-west Worcestershire.
In the old county of Merioneth, Corwen is now in Denbighshire.

See Pennant, A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, pp. 362–3: 'The prison where Owen confined his captives was not far from his house, in the parish of Llansanfraid Glyndwrdwy; and the place is to this day called Carchardy Owen Glyndwrdwy. Some remains are still to be seen near the church, which form part of a habitable house. It consists of a room thirteen feet square, and ten and a half high. The sides consist of three horizontal beams, with upright planks, not four inches asunder, mortised into them. In these are grooves with holes in the bottom, as if there had been originally cross bars, or grates. The roof is exceedingly strong, composed of strong planks almost contiguous. It seems as if there had been two stories; but the upper part at present is evidently modern.' For John Ingleby's 1794 watercolour drawing of the 'Prison of Owen Glendwr' see NLW, John Ingleby Watercolours Collection, here.
A parish and town in Flintshire. For the remains of a Dominican friary, on the site of a farm known as 'Abbey Farm', see here [accessed 17 September 2019].
A mansion on the outskirts of the village of Diserth, near Rhuddlan, Flintshire.
Cheshire
A waterfall in Caernarfonshire. See here [accessed 4 April 2019].
antiquities, Northop, Flintshire
village/hamlet, Flint, Flintshire
Denbighshire
Bagillt, Flintshire

See the description in Pennant, A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, p. 226: 'This bridge consists of two neat arches, and was first built of stone by the munificence of Gwenhwyvar, daughter of Jerwerth Ddu of Pengwern, near Llangollen; a maiden lady who resided at Eyton with her sister Margaret, who was married to Madoc ap Evan Eyton*. [ftnote: '*Eyton Pedigree'].

Overton if located in the part of Flintshire known as Maelor Saesneg (English Maelor). Records show manifestations under a range of alternative names, including 'Overton Madoc' from 1316. See Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, Place-names of Flintshire: List A (n.p., n.d.), pp. 135–17, here [accessed 29 September 2020].
A village/hamlet and mansion at Erbistock, Denbighshire.
A valley to the north east of Llangollen, Denbighshire.
A parish and village in Flintshire.
In the community of Halkyn, Flintshire. See here [accessed 4 April 2019].
?Llwyncelyn; none in Flints on Melville Richards database
village/hamlet, Caerwys, Flintshire
Flintshire, parish and village/hamlet
In the parish of Llanfor, Merioneth.

Llanfor, Penllyn, Merioneth. A circle of standing stones, now destroyed, recorded under the name 'Pabell Llywarch Hen' in the seventeenth century. It was known as the place where Llywarch Hen camped after being engaged in a battle nearby. By the end of the nineteenth century it was located in the farmyard of Pen Isa'r-Llan, but this was not its original location. Gwynedd Archaeological Trust, Historic Landscape Characterisation, Bala and Llyn Tegid – Area 6 Llanfor (PRN 24706), here @ heneb.co.uk [accessed 5 April 2019].
Llanfor, Penllyn, Merioneth.
Penllyn, Merioneth.
Flintshire.
St Mary’s Church, Dolgellau; see here [accessed 5 April 2019].
A mansion at Llanfachreth, Merioneth.

placeName.addName: Penmaen mawr, Penman Mower, Penmaenmawr, Penman Mawr
placeName.note: Mountain adjoining the north Wales coast, often noted by travellers in the period for its sublime appearance and for the dangers involved in crossing it.
Merioneth.
Northop, Flintshire. For Soughton Hall or Sychtyn Hall, dating from 1714 to 1727, see here [accessed 3 September 2019].

placeName.addName: Garden Court; Garden Court in the Temple; No. 1; No. 3

placeName.note: London

On Gothurst in Buckinghamshire (also known as Gayhurst), 'whose venerable form has not been injured by inconsistent alterations', see A journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 325–39. A drawing of Gothurst by Moses Griffith, engraved by Peter Mazell, is included at p. 324+.

For Pennant's account of Luton church see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 395–9. Notice is made of the font on p. 395, and of the 'several tombs' within an adjoining chapel on pp. 397–9.
For an account by Pennant of Northampton, see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 299–310.
Hampshire.
Site of the imprisonment of Charles I before his execution in January 1649. See here [accessed 9 August 2018].

Fisherwick Hall, Staffordshire, owned by Arthur Chichester, fifth earl of Donegall. *Hist P*; and see Pennant's reference in *The journey from Chester to London* (1782), p. 117 ('Passed through Fisherwick park, a fine seat of the Earl of Donnegal'). The house is now demolished, but for attached and related buildings still standing see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1295020 [accessed 7 August 2018].
On Acton church, Cheshire, see Pennant, The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 21–4, and the plate, 'Tomb in Acton Church', at p. 22.
Cheshire.

Shugborough, a mansion near Daventry in Warwickshire. Pennant's account of the Vale of Shugborough mentions examples of buildings of various architectural styles, as well as a 'great number of statues'. He attributed the paradisaical qualities of the place to the vision of Thomas Anson and his nephew and successor, George Anson. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 68–9; see also Moses Griffith, 'Temple of the Winds at Shugborough', Plate at p. 68; and for original drawings by Griffith held at Shugborough, here [accessed 3 September 2019].

Making nearby Shugborough his headquarters during a journey through Warwickshire, Pennant visited Tixal, noting 'its magnificent gateway, a motley pile of Gothic and Grecian architecture', built by Sir Walter Aston (d. 1589). The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 69–70.

An early seventeenth-century mansion, Ingestre Hall, or Ingestrent, Staffordshire, was described by Pennant as 'a respectable old house'. The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 72; and here [accessed 3 September 2019].
For Pennant's complete entry on Stafford, 'a good town', see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 73–8.

Located 'so that it well vindicates the propriety of its name', Pennant noted at Beaudesert in Staffordshire the 'gothic hall' of substantial dimensions (eighty by twenty-one feet), and the portrait by Holbein of the first Lord Paget. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 96–7.

Wigfair, Cefnmeiriadog, Denbighshire. Seat of the Lloyd family, whose sub-medieval house was replaced between 1882 and 1884 by a red brick building built by the Chester architect John Douglas. See here [accessed 4 September 2019].
A village in Flintshire, now known by the Welsh name Trelawnyd.
Denbighshire.
On the Isle of Wight. The mouth of the river Medina divides the town into areas designated as West and East Cowes.
St Albans or St Aldhelms headland, Dorsetshire.
The double member borough of Bere Alston, Devon, was sold to Hugh Percy, first duke of Northumberland, and left to his second son, Lord Algernon Percy. Hist P.

Isle of Wight. On the lighthouse erected at St Catherine's Point by Trinity House in 1785, see https://www.trinityhouse.co.uk/lighthouses-and-lightvessels/needles-lighthouse [accessed 9 August 2018]. An engraving of 'St. Catherine's Point' is included in Pennant, *From Dover to the Isle of Wight* (1801), p. 188.
Isle of Wight

On mainland Hampshire. On the Trinity House lighthouse erected at Hurst, south west of Hurst castle, and first lit on 29 September 1785, see https://www.trinityhouse.co.uk/lighthouses-and-lightvessels/hurst-point-lighthouse [accessed 9 August 2018].

On the Isle of Portland, Dorsetshire. Two lighthouse towers were built here in 1716. In 1789, William Johns, a builder from Weymouth, demolished and replaced one of these. See https://www.trinityhouse.co.uk/lighthouses-and-lightvessels/portland-bill-lighthouse [accessed 9 August 2018].
Queensborough Castle on the island of Sheppey, Kent. See Wenceslas Hollar digital collection at https://hollar.library.utoronto.ca/islandora/object/hollar%3AHollar_k_0931 [accessed 30 August 2018].

This may refer to 'Arms of the marquis of Dorchester' listed in Richard Pennington, *A Descriptive Catalogue of the Etched Work of Wenceslaus Hollar 1607–1677* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1982), p. 372, where it says, however, that the work is not by Hollar. The Marquis was probably Henry Pierrepont, first Marquess of Dorchester (1606–80), MP for Nottingham. See *Hist P*.

Enmore near Bridgwater, Somerset. It was rebuilt as a moated castle by John Perceval, second earl of Egmont (1711–70). See A. P. Baggs and M. C. Siraut, 'Enmore: Manors and other estates', in *A History of the County of Somerset: Volume 6, Andersfield, Cannington, and North Petherton Hundreds (Bridgwater and Neighbouring Parishes)*, ed. R. W. Dunning and C. R. Elrington (London, 1992), pp. 37–41, on British History Online @ http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/som/vol6/pp37-41 [accessed 9 August 2018]; https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1307522 [accessed 9 August 2018].

placeName.geogName: Church of St Thomas the Martyr, Winchelsea
placeName.note: The church of St Thomas the Martyr and its monuments, Winchelsea, East Sussex, are described by Pennant in 'The journey from Dover to the Isle of Wight', posthumously published as *From London to Dover* (1801), pp. 26–7. For the church see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1276072 [accessed 14 August 2018].
West Sussex. See Pennant's account in *From Dover to the Isle of Wight*, pp. 90–102; and https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000170 [accessed 16 August 2018].
Wiltshire. See https://historicengland.org.uk/services-skills/education/educational-images/longleat-house-longleat-9793 [accessed 14 August 2018].
A seaside resort and port on the Wirral Peninsula, Cheshire. See http://www.visitparkgate.co.uk/history/4552455136 [accessed 14 August 2018].
Godshill, Isle of Wight. See here [accessed 14 August 2018]; and here [accessed 9 October 2018].

Silsoe, Bedfordshire. In comments about 'the large house of Wrest', Pennant notes that 'The portraits and their history would take up a volume'. He includes an account of several pages. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 383–93.

For Pennant's account of Flitton church, 'about a mile and a half from the house [i.e. Wrest]', where monuments to the earls of Kent, their families and retainers are noted, see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 393–5.
Maulden church, 'a mile or two to the east of Ampthill'. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 382–3. See also Diana Cecil.

Houghton House is described in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 380–2, where Pennant notes that 'Two of the fronts are very beautiful; each has an elegant portico and loggio above', later drawing attention to the unequal extent of the porticos. A plate of the house from a drawing by Moses Griffith is included at p. 380.
On Ampthill Park, Bedfordshire, see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 378–80.
For Pennant's account of portraits in the house at Woburn, 'a treasure of painting', see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 347–75. This lengthy section is headed 'Woburn Abbey'.
For Horton church and the monument of William, Lord Parr, uncle to Catherine, the last queen of Henry VIII, see The journey from Chester to London, pp. 323–4.

The 'Queen's Cross' near Northampton described by Pennant in relation to his journey from Chester to London was the Hardingstone cross, one of a series of twelve crosses erected the order of Edward I to mark the locations where the body of his wife Eleanor rested on its way from Harby near Lincoln, where she died in 1290, to Westminster to be buried. See The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 322; ODNB s.n. Eleanor [Eleanor of Castile] (1241–1290).
On St. Peter's church, Northampton, 'a singular building', see The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 308.
Holy Sepulchre church, Northampton, 'supposed to have been built by the Knights Templars, on the model of that at Jerusalem'. See The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 307–8.

Castle Ashby, wrote Pennant, 'lies about six miles south-east of the town [Northampton], in a wet country, and without any advantage of situation'. He claimed that much of the work on the building (including restorative work on an older house) was attributed to Inigo Jones. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 310–16; Moses Griffith's drawing of Castle Ashby is at p. 310+.
On Easton Maudit church, Northamptonshire, and the 'very expensive monuments' within it, see A journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 319–20.
Located c. 5 km south of Daventry, Northamptonshire. See The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 292–6, where Pennant describes the hall at Fawsley House as 'a magnificent gothic room'.

Pennant writes of the 'numbers of antient [sic] tombs of the [Knightly] family within Fawsley church, but is censorious in his notice of the 'droll subjects' carved on the seats of the church. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 296–7.
South east Hampshire.
mountain range
Holborn.
El Escorial, the historical residence of the King of Spain.
Spain
Spain
Spain
Spain
France
France
Founded in 1402, the Monastery of Yuste in the province of Cáceres, Extremadura, Spain, was known in older works as San Yuste or San Just.
Spain
Spain
Spain

placeName.addName: Vale of Clwydde, Vale of Cleydd
placeName.note: Denbighshire.
Near Llanasa, Flintshire. Moses Griffith's watercolour drawing of the house is included in Pennant's extra-illustrated A Journey to Snowdon (1781), here, p. 5.
Llanasa in Flintshire is described in *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), p. 4.

Greenfield Hall, near Holywell, Flintshire. It does not appear to be mentioned in the text of either the first or the second edition of *A tour in Wales* but a watercolour by Moses Griffith, entitled 'Greenfield Hall' and dated c.1770–1800, is housed at NLW. A watercolour drawing by Moses Griffith and a second watercolour by W. N. Gardiner dated 1786 and entitled 'Basingwerk Abbey & distant View of Greenfield Hall' are included in Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4690846, p. 26.

For the Cistercian abbey of Baskingwerk, Holywell, Flintshire, see here [accessed 29 August 2018]; and Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), I, pp. 24–8, and plates IV and V. For further drawings by Moses Griffith see Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), here, p. 24/2; and A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), here, p. 24/2.

Bodowen chapel is an addition dating from 1659–61 to St Cadwaladr's Church, Llangadwaladr, Anglesey. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/43595/details/st-cadwaladrs-church-llangadwaladr [accessed 29 August 2018]. For a print dated c.1690 of a drawing by Josephus Lord, engraved by Michael Burghers, see https://viewer.library.wales/1131364#?c=0&m=0&s=0&cv=0&xywh=48%2C160%2C2539%2C3441 [accessed 29 August 2018].
Ruthven Castle, Perthshire, Scotland, now known as Huntingtower Castle. See https://www.historicenvironment.scot/visit-a-place/places/huntingtower-castle/ [accessed 29 August 2018].

Combe Abbey, Warwickshire. Pennant notes that the cloisters 'are preserved on three sides of the antient court, glazed as when occupied by their former owners, and their walls enriched with the spoils of the chace'. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 173–81, esp. 173.
Located about two miles from Coventry, 'stands the beautiful small church of [Binley], dedicated to St. Bartholomew'. The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 173.
For 'A View of Nun-Eaton Nunnery, in the County of Warwick', dated to the 1800s, see WCRO, CR 351/279, IMG: 3563, online here [accessed 3 September 2019].
On Tamworth castle see The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 122, and for the church, ibid. pp. 124–6.

In The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 81–7, Pennant writes of Blithefield, Staffordshire, describing the hall amongst the 'best rooms' of the house; gives an account of the portraits and heads (including 'a curious picture of a countrywoman of mine, Mrs. Salusbury of Bachymbed, in Denbighshire, in a vast high sugar-loafed hat and kerchief, bordered with ermine', p. 84, and a head of Molière, pp. 85–6); and provides a description of the nearby church and its tombs.
For Pennant's brief description of Wolsley park in Staffordshire, 'an inclosure of much native wild beauty', see The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 80.

Acknowledged by Sir Christopher Wren 'as a master piece of architecture', Pennant describes St. Michael's church steeple as 'a specimen of the most beautiful steeple in Europe'. See his description of it and account of its history in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 154–5.

In a description of St. Mary's Hall in Coventry, Pennant mentions 'a noble semicircular window, divided into nine parts, elegantly painted with figures of several of our monarchs [together with] some of our great nobility'. He also notes what he believed to be an ancient commode, 'an unique, which Coventry alone has the happiness of possessing ... known by the name of The Lady's Spoon, but is doubtless no other than the Scaphium of the antients.' The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 158–60.

placeName.geogName: Grey Friars steeple and gate, Coventry
placeName.note: The Grey Friars steeple was the only remaining feature of this order's church at Coventry, built during the reign of Edward III, when Pennant visited. He also noted the fine gate near the friary, but a note in a later edition states that this gate was taken down in 1781. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 160–1, 164, and including a drawing by Moses Griffith, engraved by Peter Mazell, of 'Grey Friers Gate and Steeple Coventry' as plate VIII, p. 160; The journey from Chester to London, by Thomas Pennant, Esq. with notes (London: Wilkie and Robinson; J. Nunn; White and Cochrane et al, 1811), p. 224.
Built in the late sixteenth century, Arbury Hall, Warwickshire, was remodelled along Gothic lines for Sir Roger Newdigate between 1749 and 1803. See here [accessed 3 September 2019].

Both a chapel and a friary had been built on the site of St Mary's church, Atherstone, when an additional chapel with a small nave and an octagonal bell tower were constructed on the site in (or shortly prior to) 1385. The tower was restored in 1782. Celia Parton, 'St Mary's Church, Atherstone', here [accessed 3 September 2019].

A villa, a defended settlement, an industrial complex, Roman roads and a port are among the Roman remains of Manduessedum in the parish of Mancetter, north Warwickshire. See 'Manduessedum Roman villa and settlement with associated industrial complex', here [accessed 3 September 2019].

Peerages describe Mireval Abbey in Warwickshire as the seat of Sir William Devereux, and the Magna Brittania of Daniel and Samuel Lysons notes that this abbey donated ground for the erection of a Cistercian cell at Ashborne in Derbyshire. See, e.g., Arthur Collins, The peerage of England; containing a genealogical and historical account of all the peers of that Kingdom (London: W. Strahan, J. F. and C. Rivington, J. Hinton et al, 1779), vol. III, p. 94; and Daniel and Samuel Lysons, Magna Britannia; Being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain (London: T. Cadell and W. Davies, The Strand, 1817), Vol. V, p. xvii.
Staffordshire.
For the Etruria pottery near Newcastle under Lyme, Staffordshire, see Josiah Wedgwood.

Between 1759 and 1780, the gardens at Trentham, Staffordshire, were landscaped by Lancelot Brown (known as Capability Brown, bap. 1716, d. 1783). Employed by The Earl Gower (Granville Leveson-Gower, first marquess of Stafford, 1721–1803), Brown's projects at Trentham included expanding the lake to the length of one mile by setting up a damn across the River Trent, and incorporating woodlands known as Kings Wood into the gardens. ODNB; 'Trentham Gardens', here [accessed 3 September 2019].
An archipelago in the Arctic Ocean in northern Russia. For a reference by Pennant to Novaya Zemlya, see Arctic zoology (1784), I, p. XCVI.
Cornwall.
A rocky granite pinnacle on the northern edge of St Austell Downs, Cornwall. For the medieval chapel of St Michael situated on the top of of the Rock see here [accessed 30 August 2018].
Cornwall.
City and port in the south west of Spain.
Isle of Wight.
City on the coast of Kenya.
Quiloa, or Kilwa Kisiwani, is an island off the southern coast of present-day Tanzania.
Malindi (once known as Melinde), a town on the Indian Ocean coast of Kenya.
In the Sofala Province of Mozambique, once the chief seaport of the Monomotapa Kingdom.
A port or region mentioned in the Bible.
Penmynydd, Anglesey.
Mayfair, London.
In the département of Pas-de-Calais, northern France.
On the north bank of the Thames, the Steelyard was the Hanseatic League's primary trading base in London during the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
City of Westminster, London.
Richmond upon Thames. See here [accessed 5 September 2018].

Set in a corner of St James's Park and originally formed in Elizabethan times as an addition to the pleasure grounds of Whitehall Palace, Spring Gardens were a fashionable quarter during the eighteenth century, inhabited by politicians and civil servants. See 'Spring Gardens', in *Survey of London: Volume 20, St Martin-in-The-Fields, Pt III: Trafalgar Square and Neighbourhood*, ed. G H Gater and F R Hiorns (London, 1940), pp. 58-65. British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-london/vol20/pt3/pp58-65 [accessed 5 September 2018].
Harecastle, Staffordshire.

placeName.addName: the canal now working beneath [Hare castle]
placeName.note: For Pennant's comments on the 'Grand Trunk Canal' 'begun on July 17th, 1766, near the south end of Hare-castle Hill[, Staffordshire]', for the purpose of joining the 'eastern and western oceans', see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 50–2. Notice is also made of two tunnels created to allow the canal to follow its course, one of which is a 2,880 yard tunnel through the mountain at Hare Castle. Ibid., p. 52.

A Jacobean hall built for Sir Randolph [or Randle, vide Pennant] Crew between 1615 and 1636, possibly based on designs by Inigo Jones. Pennant notes a monument to 'Johannes Crew' at Nantwich church, and describes his son, Randle, as 'the founder of the respectable house of Crew, near this town'. The journey from Chester to London (1811), p. 44. Writing of a portrait of Sir Randle Crew at Wrest, Bedfordshire, he further notes that the latter 'built the magnificent seat of Crew Hall; and was the first who brought the model of good building into that distant county.' The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 389. See also here [accessed 3 September 2019].
Lynton, Cheshire.
Admiral Rodney’s Pillar, a monument raised on Breiddin Hill, just outside Welshpool, in 1782 to commemorate the naval victories of George Brydges Rodney in the American Wars of Independence.
Thirteenth-century Welsh-built castle (much altered in the following centuries) overlooking the town of Welshpool. See http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/29858/details/powis-castle-powys-castle
Former coaching inn described in the period as one of Welshpool’s two main inns (the other was The Bear).
Seventeenth-century coaching inn in Llangadfan, Montgomeryshire. See http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/28923/details/cann-office-hotel-llangadfan
Inn at Mallwyd, now named The Brigands Inn. In his A Tour through Part of North Wales, in the Year 1798 (London, 1800), John Evans noted that it was run by the Lloyd family (see pp. 54-5).
Village on the River Banwy, Montgomeryshire, Powys.

The county town of the former county of Merioneth (Sir Feirionnydd). For sketches of the road to Dolgellau made on a tour of 1819 by Sarah Grace Carr see:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:NLW_Drawing_volume_DV398_-_Sketches_by_Sarah_Grace_Carr_during_a_tour_of_Wales#/media/File:DV_398_Dolgellau,_Aug_25_1819.png

Beauty spot in Snowdonia, famously etymologized as 'bedd' (grave) 'Gelert' (the name of Prince Llywelyn's faithful hound). For the growth of the legend and its influence on tourism to this day see Michael Freeman, ‘Early Accounts of the Legend of Gelert the Greyhound and His Grave’, Transactions of the Caernarvonshire Historical Society, vol. 77 (2016-2017), pp. 40-59 and https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/attractions/gelerts-grave-at-beddgelert/
Castle built under the direction of Edward I in the late-thirteenth century as part of the conquest of Wales.

One of the most admired places on the north Wales tour, Festiniog was praised by Lord Lyttelton in 1756 as a rural idyll: 'with the woman one loves, with the friend of one's heart and a good study of books one might pass an age there and think it a day.' (Addendum to Henry Penruddocke-Wyndham, A Gentleman's Tour 1771 (new ed.1781), 556-57. For Moses Griffith's lovely view of the village in Pennant's Extra-Illustrated Tour in Wales see:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:A_Tour_in_Wales_by_Thomas_Pennant#/media/File:Festiniog_02386.jpg

A valley and formerly estuary through which the River Glaslyn runs from Snowdon to the coast. Marshland adjoining the river comprising thousands of acres was reclaimed in the late 1790s and early 1800s by the landowner and MP William Madocks (1773-1828), who constructed an embankment across the estuary near Porthmadog. For a contemporary depiction of the embankment, see here [accessed 2 September 2019].

Bridge across the Aberglaslyn gorge near Beddgelert, Snowdonia, and a key feature in the landscape for visiting writers and painters in the period. See, for example, Mary Smirke (1779- 1853), ‘Pont Aberglasslyn’ (c.1810): https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pont_Aberglasslyn_(1132552).jpg)
Llyn Cwellyn is a notably deep lake running alongside the Beddgelert-Caernarfon road, not far from the foot of Snowdon.

Village at the foot of Snowdon, and a key site for the development of tourism and of the slate industry in North Wales. What many C18th tourists refer to as Llanberis, however, is the original settlement, now known as Nant Peris, higher up the valley. The church of St Peris is located here; St Padarn's is in modern Llanberis.

A key site in the development of C19th tourism in Snowdonia after the construction of the new road from Bangor by Lord Penrhyn at the end of the C18th. For an extensive collection of accounts see Michael Freeman: https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/practicalities/accommodation/inns/capel-curig-inn/

A steep-sided glacial valley in Snowdonia, leading to Bethesda, between the Glyderau and the Carneddau mountains. The first coach road through Nant Ffrancon was built by Lord Penrhyn in the late C18th, and connected Caernarfon with his Inn at Capel Curig in the heart of the Snowdon range. For a contemporary sketch of the valley, by Joshua Cristall (1802), see here.
Castle on the north Wales coast built by Edward 1 in the 1280s as part of his efforts to conquer Wales; see http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/121/details/conwy-castle
Three-arched bridge dating from the early seventeenth century, said to have been built by Inigo Jones, though the connection to Jones is uncertain. See here.
Gwydir Castle, Tudor manor house and seat of the Wynn family; see http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/26555/details/gwydir-castle and http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-WYNN-GWY-1300.html
Hill in the Clwydian Range, in north-east Wales.
Thirteenth-century castle set on a dramatic crag, incorporating an iron age hillfort, and partly destroyed during the Civil War.
For a contemporary illustration of these streets, known as ‘The Rows’, see Thomas Webster’s 1807 watercolour sketch: http://collections.britishart.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3656906
A limestone cave just south of Buxton.
Lead mine west of Castleton. See http://www.derbyshireheritage.co.uk/Menu/Archaeology/Mines/Lead/odin-mine.php
Hill near Castleton, affording dramatic views over the Peak District.
Cave near Castleton. For an eighteenth-century illustration of its setting, see: http://www.revolutionaryplayers.org.uk/north-west-view-of-castleton-castle-and-the-devils-arse-in-the-peak/
A sixteenth-century stately home and seat of the Duke of Devonshire.
A fortified medieval manor house.
A Robert Adam-designed country house near Derby.
The University of Oxford’s C17th ceremonial hall, designed by Sir Christopher Wren.
A circular, domed neoclassical library (now university reading room), built in the 1730s and 40s.
Villa in Central Italy, constructed for the Emperor Hadrian in the 2nd century AD. See: http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/907
Constituent college of the University of Oxford, founded by Henry VIII in 1546, which holds an important collection of Old Master paintings.

Designed by Sir Christopher Wren and built in the 1680s, this tower at Christ Church is a well-known Oxford landmark: see http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/turner-oxford-tom-tower-christ-church-d00155 for Turner’s early-1790s depiction of it.
Oxford college founded in 1438; its library, designed by Nicholas Hawksmoor, was completed in 1751. The library was financed by and named after the West Indian slave owner Christopher Codrington.
Constituent college of the University of Oxford, founded in 1379.
Principal university library in Oxford, opened in 1602.
Constituent college of the University of Oxford, founded in 1458.
Inn on Cornmarket, one of Oxford’s central streets.
Constituent college of the University of Oxford, founded in 1264.

Kenilworth Castle, in Warwickshire, dates from the C12th but was partly ruined during the Civil War. It became a fashionable tourist destination in the C18th – something that was celebrated and furthered by the publication of Walter Scott’s Kenilworth; a Romance in 1821: http://www.walterscott.lib.ed.ac.uk/works/novels/kenilw.html

The stone-built Warwick Castle dates from the C13th. By the early C19th it was the family home of the Greville family. The earliest known inventory of the collection at Warwick Castle was made by Thomas Pennant in 1774: see http://www.ourwarwickshire.org.uk/content/article/connoisseur-collector-george-greville-2nd-earl-warwick
Country house in Tremeirchion in north-east Wales, built by Hester and Gabriel Piozzi, who had lived there since 1795.

Notably early brick-built house in Tremeirchion, built for Sir Richard Clough in the 1560s, which became the Salusbury family home. For the house as depicted in the extra-illustrated Tours in Wales held at the National Library of Wales, see: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bachegraig_House,_Tremeichion._Home_of_Richard_Clough.jpg
Cathedral in St Asaph, constructed and restored at various points across the 12-14th centuries, and later remodelled across the 18-20th centuries; see here.
Near Oswestry in the north of Shropshire.
Crossing point from the mainland to the island of Anglesey, before the opening of Thomas Telford's suspension bridge in 1826.
Tidal channel separating the Welsh mainland from the island of Anglesey.
Castle built by Edward I from 1283 onwards as part of his efforts to conquer Wales; see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95318/details/caernarfon-castle-caernarfon
The Sportsman Hotel, in Castle Street, Caernarfon. For a nineteenth-century illustration of the hotel, see https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/23629
Georgian villa built by William Madocks. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/16896/details/tan-yr-allt
Country house in Snowdonia, owned first by the Griffith family and then by the Oakeley family, much remodelled in the nineteenth century. See here and here.

Formal gardens which included a picturesque walk to the waterfall Rhaeadr Du; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/301630/details/dolmelynllyndol-y-melynllyn-garden-ganllwyd. For a contemporary depiction by J. S. Duncan, see also https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:DV_77_No.61_Dolymelynllyn.png

Rhaeadr Du ('Black Falls'), two waterfalls on the Afon Gamlan in Snowdonia. For a nineteenth-century depiction of the falls, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?search=rhaeadr+du&title=Special:Search&profile=default&fulltext=1&searchToken=co169ttnt8hbqplbonwnlcwvd#/media/File:Rhaiadyr_Du,_near_Tan_y_Bwlch,_Merionethshire_(1133779).jpg
House owned by Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, set on the shore of Bala Lake, built by 1804; see https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/material-culture/buildings/retreats/
Villa on Bala Lake owned by Sir Richard Colt Hoare, named Fach Deilog/Fachddeiliog; see https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/material-culture/buildings/retreats/
Coaching inn on the Holyhead Road, between Corwen and Betws-y-Coed; see http://curioustravellers.ac.uk/en/the-cernioge-inn-a-forgotten-spot-on-the-welsh-tour/
Country house near Denbigh, home of Cecilia Thrale after her marriage to John Meredith Mostyn (d. 1807).
Penrhyn slate quarry, developed by Richard Pennant in the later eighteenth century, becoming the largest slate quarry in the world by the end of the nineteenth.
Ogwen Bank, a Gothic villa built by Richard Pennant to designs by Benjamin Wyatt, c. 1790; see https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/material-culture/buildings/retreats/
A late medieval country house near Denbigh, built for the Myddleton family. Thomas Pennant, Samuel Johnson and Hester Thrale Piozzi all spent time here.
Country house south of Denbigh
South-east Hampshire.
Snaefell, 620.9m above sea level, is the highest mountain on the Isle of Man.
Coastal town in the north of the Isle of Man.
The Point of Ayre in Ramsey Bay, Isle of Man, the northernmost point on the island.
In the south of the Isle of Man.
Scarlett, Isle of Man – an area of Carboniferous limestone in which wildlife and plants thrive, and which yielded limestone for quarrying as late as the nineteenth century.
Village on the east coast of the Isle of Man.
Douglas, Isle of Man.
Isle of Man. This place has not been identified.
Isle of Man. This place has not been identified.
Isle of Man.
Aber, Caernarfonshire.
Site of a Roman river crossing over the Conwy, north Wales.
A mountain pass between Dolgellau and Dinas Mawddwy associated in the C16th with a notorious family of red-haired bandits, the Gwylliaid Cochion Mawddwy. See Pennant, Tours in Wales (1784) II, 93-95.
Eisteddfa Gurig, Cardiganshire.
Elfael, commot and lordship which later made up the southern part of Brecknockshire.
Buellt or Buallt, commot and lordship, in southern Powys.
A mid-Wales medieval commot.
A medieval commot in Montgomeryshire.
Cantref and lordship in east central Wales.
Ceri, Montgomeryshire.
Pont Gamarch, Carmarthenshire.
Llandandras, Radnorshire.
Aqueduct that carries the Llangollen Canal across the River Dee, built by Thomas Telford and William Jessop and completed in 1805. See here.

The Lion Inn, Shrewsbury – Coaching inn dating from the late fifteenth century; see http://search.shropshirehistory.org.uk/collections/getrecord/CCS_MSA5477/
Described by Thomas J. Howell in 1816:The Lion Inn on Wyle Cop is kept by Mr Tomkins. For elegant accommodation and the greatest attention it is not surpassed. The London Holy head and Ludlow mails run to this house, also coaches regularly from hence to London Holyhead Worcester Hereford Bath Cheltenham Birmingham Chester Liverpool Manchester and all parts of the kingdom. (The Stranger in Shrewsbury, 1816).
Eleventh-century castle built following the Norman Conquest. By the eighteenth century the castle was largely in ruins following the Civil War.
A seventeenth-century house, owned in this period by Edward Foley (1747-1803) and Edward Thomas Foley (1791-1846). See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000897
An early eighteenth-century stately home, built for the 1st Duke of Marlborough (1650–1722); see http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/425

Cottage (literally named ‘new hall’) overlooking Llangollen, and home of Eleanor Butler and Sarah Ponsonby between 1780 and 1831. Butler and Ponsonby made significant alterations to the house, which, along with its owners, became famous as part of the North Wales tourist trail and in popular culture. See here.
See also 'Port Jackson' (pl2517).

For a discussion of Newgate Prison during the eighteenth century, including accounts by the prison reformer John Howard of a visit there in 1779 and of the destruction of the gaol during the Gordon Riots of the following year, see Walter Thornbury, 'Newgate', in Old and New London: Volume 2 (London, 1878), pp. 441–61. British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/old-new-london/vol2/pp441-461 [accessed 11 September 2018].
Hampshire.
A pass in the Pyrenees, on the Spanish side of the border.
For Goodwood House and its surrounding garden and park, see *https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000157* [accessed 17 September 2018].
Street in south-eastern corner of Grosvernor Square, later renamed Grosvenor Street.

Mansion just outside Bangor, built in the 1780s on the site of a fifteenth-century house, but much extended and remodelled from the 1820s onwards; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/16687/details/penrhyn-castle-bangor [accessed 18 September 2018].
Near the western tip of Brittany.

placeName.geogName: Trinity College Church And Hospital, Edinburgh

placeName.note: St Mael and St Sulien’s, early medieval church; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/43882/details/st-mael-and-st-suliensst-suliens-corwen For a contemporary depiction by Moses Griffith, see also https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:DV_27_No.11.Corwen_Church.png
Penmorfa Gwynedd was, before the C19th embankment changed the coastline, the settlement at the edge of the Caernarfonshire crossing of Traeth Mawr. It has a medieval church dedicated to St Beuno.
Irish capital, in the province of Leinster.
A former Roman settlement possibly at the site of Harcourt Park, Shropshire, named in the Antonine Itinerary (Iter II). See roman-britain.co.uk [accessed 12 April 2018].
A pass on the Berwyn mountains, near the highest point of the range, Cadair Bronwen.

An ancient trackway which can be traced running South East from the stone noting the boundary of Llanarmon Dyffryn Ceiriog. Its name links it with a Roman road between Forden Gaer and Bala or Llanfor, but in view of the fact that a road has been traced between Caersws and Caer Gai, near Llanuwchllyn, this association is probably erroneous. coflein.gov.uk [accessed 4 April 2018].

Located on an isolated hill in the community of Llangedwyn, in the old county of Denbighshire, Llwyn Bryn-Dinas hillfort appears to have been in use in both the Bronze and Iron Ages. coflein.gov.uk [accessed 12 April 2018].
This probably refers to Cwm Maen Gwynedd in the community of Llanrhaeadr-ym-mochnant.
vale

Pennant notes that Longnor Hall, near Longnor, the home of his friend, Joseph Plymley, is a 'good brick house, built in 1670 by Sir Richard [Corbet], a predecessor of the late owner'. A tour in Wales (1778), II, p. 416.
For Pennant's account of St Margaret's church, Westminster, see Some account of London. Second Edition (London: Faulder, 1791), pp. 86–7.
A historical Royal Forest, occupying areas now covered by Epping and Hainault Forests in Greater London and Essex.
Winchester district, Hampshire. Southwick Park was replaced c.1820 by the Regency mansion known as Southwick House, for which see here [accessed 25 September 2018].

placeName.addName: Church Stretton, Little Stretton, All Stretton

placeName.note: A village in Montgomeryshire, six miles south-west of Oswestry.

Site in north-east Anglesey where copper has been extracted since the Bronze Age, but which dramatically increased production in the eighteenth century. The mine and surrounding area, which displayed the devastating effects of industrial pollution, was a key site for artists and travel writers in the period. Thomas Pennant was an important early commentator on the mines in this period. For a contemporary visual depiction of excavations at Parys, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Paris_Mines_in_the_year_1800.jpeg
Ancient city in Mali.
Waterfront district of Naples.
Prebends Bridge in the centre of Durham, built 1772-8. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1121354
Alnwick Castle, 13th/14th-century stately home in Northumberland, and seat of the Duke of Northumberland. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1001041
Brizlee Tower, a 26-metre high folly constructed for Hugh Percy in 1781 as a memorial to his wife, Elizabeth. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1076985
The Borghese Chapel is situated opposite the Sistine Chapel, in the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore in Rome.
The mid eighteenth-century palace, gardens and 3-tiered aqueduct at Caserta, near Naples, were designed by Luigi Vanvitelli. See http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/549.
Early 18th-century palladian mansion in Essex, demolished in 1825; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000194
Edinburgh’s Botanical Garden dates back to 1670. In 1789, it was situated near Holyrood Abbey.
The New Inn later became Arrochar Hotel. See Dorothy Wordsworth, Recollections of a Tour Made in Scotland, ed. Carol Kyros Walker (Yale University Press, 1997) p. 118.

Drumpellier House, west of Glasgow, owned in the late eighteenth century by Andrew Stirling, nephew of Andrew Buchanan, a merchant and later Provost of the University of Glasgow, who had built it in the 1740s.
Mountain range in the Lake District including the peak Helvellyn.
Second-largest lake in the Lake District at some 9 miles in length.
For Hester Piozzi’s account of Lake Lugano in her Observations and Reflections Made in the Course of a Journey through France, Italy, and Germany (1789), see II. 233.
Area to the south of Derwentwater.

The Avernus is a lake north of Naples, identified with the underworld because of its beautiful but gloomy setting and its classical associations, as in François Fénelon’s Les Aventures de Télémache (1699), but also in Hester Piozzi’s own account of the area around the Avernus in Observations and Reflections (II. 12).

Graphite had long been mined in the Borrowdale Fells. See Stephen Copley, ‘William Gilpin and the black-lead mine’, in Stephen Copley and Peter Garside (eds), The Politics of the Picturesque: Literature, Landscape and Aesthetics Since 1770 (Cambridge University Press, 1994), pp. 42-61.

At around a mile in length, Belle Isle is the largest of 18 islands on Windermere. Its neoclassical roundhouse was built in the 1770s by John Christian (later Christian Curwen). See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000661

Single arched bridge over the River Taff, completed in 1756. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/24145/details/pontypridd-old-bridge-pontypridd. For a contemporary depiction of the bridge, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pont_y_Pridd_(1133652).jpg.

Norman-medieval castle overlooking the River Wye, part of a string of fortresses on the Wales-England border (see also Monmouth Castle, Chepstow Castle), significantly damaged during the Civil War. By the eighteenth century the castle had fallen into ruin. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1014904

Eleventh-century castle overlooking the River Wye, and part of a chain of fortresses on the Wales-England border (see also Goodrich Castle, Chepstow Castle). See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/93473/details/monmouth-castle
Twelfth-century Cistercian abbey, on the banks of the River Wye in south-east Wales. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/359/details/tintern-abbey
Monmouthshire.
Piercefield House and park, eighteenth-century country house and picturesque gardens, north of Chepstow. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95237/details/chepstow-castle

Eleventh-century castle overlooking the River Wye, and part of a chain of fortresses on the Wales-England border (see also Goodrich Castle, Monmouth Castle). See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95237/details/chepstow-castle
Seventeenth-century (possibly sixteenth-century) coaching inn in the centre of Chepstow.
Fifteenth-century castle between Monmouth and Usk, much damaged during the Civil War. See here [accessed 26 June 2020].

Early church later remodelled as an Augustinian priory in the early twelfth century, which fell into ruin after the Dissolution of the Monasteries. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95238/details/llanthony-priory-llanthony-abbey
Norman castle north-west of Crickhowell, built over the twelfth and thirteenth centuries. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/306010/details/tretower-castle

What became Brecon Cathedral in the 1920s was previously known as Brecon’s Parish Church, which incorporated the remains of the eleventh/twelfth-century Priory of St John the Evangelist. See https://www.breconcathedral.org.uk/httpwwwbreconcathedralorgukhistory/introduction/

Norman castle, built in the late eleventh century. In 1809, Sir Charles Morgan began renovating the castle, part of which was incorporated into a new hotel – the Castle Hotel. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/92021/details/brecon-castle
Eighteenth-century coaching inn in Llandovery. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/17183/details/castle-hotel-kings-road
Thirteenth-century Norman castle built on the site of a previous motte and bailey. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/92751/details/llandovery-castle

Welsh-built castle set on a crag near Llandeilo, Carmarthenshire, with a chequered history of Welsh and English ownership. It was substantially damaged in the fifteenth century during the Wars of the Roses; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/103970/details/carreg-cennen-castle
Welsh-built castle set on a ridge overlooking the River Tywi. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/425/details/dinefwr-castle-llandeilo
Eighteenth-century coaching inn in Carmarthen.

Cathedral in north-west Pembrokeshire constructed in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries on the site of a sixth-century church. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/306/details/st-davids-cathedral-st-davids-cathedral See also http://www.stdavidscathedral.org.uk/index.php?id=678
Norman castle near Haverfordwest, built in the twelfth/thirteenth centuries. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/102780/details/roch-castle
Ruined medieval palace alongside the cathedral; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/21633/details/st-davids-bishops-palace

Norman castle built in the thirteenth century. By the eighteenth century it had been remodelled as a mansion and home of the Phillipps family. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/103578/details/picton-castle-slebech In the early nineteenth century, it was owned by Richard Philipps, 1st Baron Milford (1744-1823).

Late eighteenth-century country house in Pembrokeshire; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/30244/details/slebech-hall The Mr Phillips who owned it in the early nineteenth century was Nathaniel Phillips (1733-1813), a Jamaican sugar plantation owner; see https://www.ucl.ac.uk/lbs/person/view/1330090056
Pembrokeshire.
Early eighteenth-century mansion in south Pembrokeshire, seat of the Campbell family (Lords of Cawdor in Scotland); see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/125/details/stackpole-court-stackpole
A medieval pilgrimage chapel set against a limestone cliff on the south Pembrokeshire coast. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95059/details/st-govans-chapel-bosherston
Thirteenth and fourteenth-century Bishop’s Palace, part of the estate of St David’s; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/22223/details/lamphey-bishops-palace
Late thirteenth-early fourteenth century castle, much damaged during the Civil War. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/92709/details/carew-castle

Norman castle built in the twelfth century, which switched between Welsh and English ownership several times over the following two centuries. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95725/details/llanstephan-castle-llansteffan-castle
A small tidal island at the south-west end of the Gower Peninsula.

Norman castle dating from the eleventh century onwards, much damaged during the revolt of Owain Glyndŵr in the early fifteenth century. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95633/details/kidwelly-castle-kidwelly
Cistercian monastery founded in the twelfth century, in ruins by the eighteenth century. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/133/details/neath-abbey
Cistercian monastery founded in the twelfth century. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/132/details/margam-abbey

Penrice Castle, house on the Gower Peninsula built in the 1770s by Thomas Mansel Talbot as a replacement for Margam House, demolished by 1793; see https://www.peoplescollection.wales/collections/377908. See also http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/19670/details/penrice-castle-mansion
Built for Thomas Mansel Talbot at Margam in the late 1780s and early 1790s. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/37606/details/margam-castle-orangery
Late eighteenth-century coaching inn.

Twelfth-century castle on the Glamorganshire coast. For a contemporary depiction by William Daniell, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:St._Donats,_Glamorganshire.jpeg. See also http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/300312/details/st-donats-castleatlantic-collegeunited-world-college-of-the-atlantic-st-donats
Estate near the Somerset coast, owned in this period by the Acland family.

Twelfth-century cathedral in Llandaff, Cardiff; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/131/details/llandaff-cathedral. For a contemporary view of the cathedral, see also https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Llandaff_cathedral_(1133661).jpg

From its beginnings as an eleventh-century Norman castle (built on the site of a Roman fort), by the eighteenth century Cardiff Castle was owned by the Marquess of Bute, who remodelled much of the castle and its grounds. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/33/details/cardiff-castle

Thirteenth-century Norman castle, which became a focal point for conflict between the Welsh and Anglo-Normans through the middle ages. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/94497/details/caerphilly-castle
Hotel on Dowry Square, in the Hotwells area of Bristol. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1202212

placeName.geogName: London Coffee-House, Punch-house, Dorchester Beer and Welsh Ale Warehouse

placeName.note: Bendictine abbey in Padua, northern Italy.

Sizergh Castle, a medieval mansion near Kendal, owned by the Strickland family. Cecilia Strickland (1741-1814), who lived there in the late eighteenth century, was one of Hester Piozzi’s oldest friends; see Edward A. Bloom and Lillian D. Bloom (eds), The Piozzi Letters: Correspondence of Hester Lynch Piozzi, 1784-1821 (formerly Mrs. Thrale) Volume 1, 1784-1791 (University of Delaware Press, 1989), p. 81. See also https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1318962
Levens Hall, an Elizabethan manor house south of Kendal. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1350017

Chester Cathedral, built from red sandstone, represents a range of architectural styles, the earliest of which dates from the 11th century. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1376398

Garthewin House, a 17th and 18th-century country house south of Abergele, owned by the Wynne family – longstanding friends of Hester Piozzi’s. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/27186/details/garthwin-garthewin
Maesmynan Hall, near Caerwys in Flintshire.
Flintshire.
Parish church in Ludlow, parts of which date to the thirteenth century; see https://historicengland.org.uk/services-skills/grants/visit/st-laurence-ludlow-sy8-1an/

Hereford Cathedral, parts of which date from the 11th century, was undergoing significant repair work in the later eighteenth century, following the collapse of one of its towers in 1786. See also https://historicengland.org.uk/services-skills/education/educational-images/hereford-cathedral-4680
Regensburg, in south-east Germany.

Mayfair, London, the building of which began in 1717 and was designed to honour the Hanoverian king, George I. See Edward Walford, 'Hanover Square and neighbourhood', in Old and New London: Volume 4 (London, 1878), pp. 314–26, British History Online, here [accessed 6 September 2019].
The River Vyrnwy (Welsh Efyrnwy) now rises in a large lake of the same name formed by damming in the 1880s. It joins the River Severn at Melverley in Shropshire.

Cader (or Cadair) Idris, a mountain to the south of the coastal town of Dolgellau in Snowdonia. It was much painted by artists, including this famous painting of Llyn y Cau by Richard Wilson, possibly exhibited in 1774: https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/wilson-llyn-y-cau-cader-idris-n05596
Twelfth-century Norman castle, partly damaged during the Civil War. See http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/94195/details/manorbier-castle
Pembroke River flows through Lamphey to Pembroke Castle.

Gloucester Cathedral was built from the 11th century onwards, and is famous for its fan-vaulted ceiling, dating from the mid-14th century, which is thought to be the earliest example of its kind. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1245952
Eighteenth-century coaching inn in Pembrokeshire.
St Grwst’s Church, part of which dates to the fifteenth century; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/55093/details/st-grwsts-church-llanrwst
Thirteenth-century Norman castle, subjected to repeated attacks from the turn of the fourteenth century until left to ruin after the Civil War; see here.
Eighteenth-century inn at Dolgellau; see here

The Cors-y-Gedol Arms was named after the local estate of the Vaughan family; as Michael Freeman notes, Barmouth was for a while an ‘exclusive’ resort, since it took travellers considerable effort and expense to get there. See here. For a late C19th image of the hotel see here.
Inn on Castle Street in Caernarfon.

Designed by Benjamin Wyatt for Lord Penrhyn, the new Inn at Capel Curig was in business by 1800, but continually improved and developed thereafter. It had spectacular views. For visitors' accounts see https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/practicalities/accommodation/inns/capel-curig-inn/
Coaching Inn at Abergwyngregyn, on the road between Bangor and Conwy
Inn at Conwy, kept by a Mrs Read and her daughters. Samuel Read had taken over the running of the pub in 1778.
On the history of Eton College, founded in 1440 by Henry VI, see here [accessed 5 November 2018].

https://canmore.org.uk/site/23234/dun-mac-sniachan A site near the fort of Dun Mac Sniachan on Ardmucknish Bay was spuriously identified with the royal city of Fergus II by the fifteenth-century Scottish historian, Hector Boece. Despite the unreliabilty of the attribution, it was taken up by subsequent writers and travellers and is marked on James Dorret's 'A general map of Scotland and islands thereto belonging' (London: 1750). Beregonium is also mentioned in Sinclair's Statistical Account of Scotland (Edinburgh: 1791-1799) and (with a degree of scepticism) in Pennant, A Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774), p.411. See also Richard Pococke, Tours in Scotland 1747, 1750, 1760, ed. by Daniel William Kemp (Edinburgh: Scottish History Society, 1887), p.69 and Robert Angus Smith, Loch Etive and the Sons of Uisnach, (London: 1879).

Located on a site near the present-day Lyceum Theatre in the Strand, The Lyceum was the Exhibition Room of the Society of Artists of Great Britain. It was designed during 1771–2 by the architect James Paine ([Payne]; bap. 1717?, d. 1789), then president of the Society. The splitting up of the Society on the formation of the Royal Academy in 1768 led to stiff competition and to the eventual failure of the venture at the Strand. The building was sold and converted into a theatre before its eventual demolition in 1815. ODNB; https://www.regencyhistory.net/2017/06/the-lyceum-theatre-in-regency-london.html [accessed 5 September 2018].

For 'Graig Dalar Goch' ['Dalar Goch Rock'] in the parish of Dyserth, Flintshire, see here [accessed 3 October 2018].

A stone-built castle in the community of Dyserth, Flintshire. Built by Henry III from 1241, it was later demolished by Llywelyn ap Gruffudd. See Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), p. 7; here [accessed 3 October 2018] and Dalar Goch.

One of the longest rivers in Asia, running the entire length of Pakistan. Pennant opens vol. XIV of 'Outlines of the Globe' with a description of 'the mighty river' Sind, later known by the name Indus, which forms 'the boundary between the Persian and Indian dominions'. He states his intention 'to proceed down to its Delta, where it is discharged into the sea, and briefly point out the most remarkable places, antient or modern, which occur in my course'. See Pennant, The view of Hindoostan: Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798), pp. 1–2.

The name used by the Greeks for the river Jhelum in Punjab, Pakistan. See The view of Hindoostan: Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798), p. 43, where Pennant introduces this as 'the most celebrated of the five rivers, the Fabulous Hydaspes'. See also ibid., p. 17, where alternative names for the river, 'the modern Behut, or Chelum', are noted.
The Euphrates flows from its source in eastern Turkey through Syria and Iraq to join the Tigris before entering the Persian Gulf.

This is probably the Blue Bell, Rhosesmor Road, Halkyn, Flintshire, built in the middle of the eighteenth century. See here [accessed 24 October 2018]. Note also the Old Blue Bell at Overton, Flintshire. See here [accessed 24 October 2018].
The Sublime or Ottoman Porte was the court or palace of the Ottoman sultan at Istanbul. References to it by extension allude to the Ottoman government. OED.

See Helge Kökeritz, The Place-names of the Isle of Wight (Nomina Germanica, 6) (Uppsala: Appelberg, 1940), where Wootton Bridge is listed as a twentieth-century name for the village of Wootton, situated between Ryde and Newport on the Isle of Wight. Kökeritz's research into the name also offers the form 'Utton Bridge', dating to c.1536. It seems likely that Richard Bull's reference in 1139 is to the village in its entirety. See here [accessed 9 October 2018].

A cottage near St Lawrence in the Undercliff of the Isle of Wight. Built as an addition to a seventeenth- or eighteenth-century building, known as 'The Old Cottage', 'The Cottage St Lawrence Well' (also known as 'Sea Cottage' and, later, 'Marine Villa') was the marine residence of Sir Richard Worsley, completed in 1794. Worsley retired here with his mistress from c.1788, a Mrs Sarah Smith, had the grounds adorned with classical temples and attempted to have a vineyard planted. See ODNB; and here [accessed 9 October 2018].

Clifford’s Tower is an 11th-century timber tower on top of an earth mound built as a motte and bailey castle by William the conqueror in York. Burnt down in 1190, a stone tower was built as a replacement in the thirteenth century, and this stands today. In the eighteenth century it was treated as a garden folly and possibly as a stable or cattle shed. It is not clear whether Pennant visited Clifford's Tower. See https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/cliffords-tower-york/history-and-stories/history/ [accessed 6 December 2018].

Created following Napoléon's successful campaigns of 1796 and 1797 in northern Italy, the Cisalpine Republic incorporated Lombardy, the duchy of Modena, Massa-Carra and the Cispadane Republic, Valtellina, Brescia and Bergamo. A draft constitution of July 1797 was amended by December 1797, and replaced again in September 1798 following a coup d'état in April 1798. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 140.

The River Liffey runs through the centre of Dublin, before flowing out into the Irish Sea.

Irish county located to the south of Dublin. For an account of picturesque tourism and Wicklow in the period, by Finola O’Kane, see https://www.bl.uk/picturing-places/articles/the-military-roads-of-county-wicklow

Early eighteenth-century building, situated on the north side of College Green in Dublin, which housed first the Irish Parliament and, after 1800, the headquarters of the Bank of Ireland. For a modern photograph of the building, see https://digital.ucd.ie/view/ivrla:31405

Building in Dublin constructed from 1776 onwards, originally built to house the four divisions of the Irish judicial system (the courts of Chancery, King’s Bench, Exchequer and Common Pleas); see http://www.buildingsofireland.ie/niah/search.jsp?type=record&county=DU&regno=50070269

Riverside neoclassical building in Dublin, constructed in the late eighteenth century, whose grandeur was intended to convey the city’s importance as a centre of trade and commerce in the period; see http://www.buildingsofireland.ie/niah/search.jsp?type=record&county=DU&regno=50060555

A narrow glacial valley on the border between County Dublin and County Wicklow. For a contemporary illustration of the valley, see http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/kinggeorge/t/003ktop00000055u052b0000.html

Irish river rising in the Wicklow Mountains, which flows out into the Irish Sea at Bray. Noted for its picturesque qualities as part of the Wicklow tour; see, for example, https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/dargle-county-of-wicklow

Highest mountain in England and Wales, at 1085 metres. Explored early by botanists, it became a favourite destination for tourists. Thomas Pennant's description of two ascents was highly influential (Tours in Wales, 1784 II, 170-73); it may have influenced Wordsworth's account in the final book of the 1805 Prelude of his own ascent. For an extensive survey of tourist accounts of the mountain, see here.
