For a contemporary depiction of the cathedral, by Joseph Faringdon, see https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/farington-north-east-view-of-worcester-cathedral-t08449
Chantry Chapel of Prince Arthur (eldest son of Henry VII), at Worcester Cathedral; see http://www.worcestercathedral.co.uk/Prince_Arthur.php

Late eighteenth-century vicarage in Hanbury, Worcestershire; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1374436. For a contemporary view of the church and vicarage at Hanbury, see https://www.search.staffspasttrack.org.uk/Details.aspx?&ResourceID=8154&PageIndex=51&SearchType=2&ThemeID=454

placeName.geogName: Church of St Mary the Virgin
placeName.note: Parish church in Hanbury, Worcestershire, part of which date to the thirteenth century; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1350133
Early eighteenth-century country house in Hanbury, Worcestershire; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1350164
Village in Worcestershire.
Seventeenth-century inn at Winchcombe, Gloucestershire; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1091504
Village in Gloucestershire.
Sixteenth/seventeenth-century hotel in Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1170902
Seventeenth/eighteenth-century hotel in Woodstock; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1052853
Chapel of New College, Oxford. For a series of modern photographs of the chapel's interior, see https://www.new.ox.ac.uk/node/1360
Chapel of Magdalen College, Oxford. For a modern photograph of the interior of the chapel, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Magdalen_College_Chapel_Interior,_Oxford,_UK_-_Diliff.jpg
Area of grassland adjacent to Clare College, Cambridge.
Chapel at King's College, Cambridge. For a contemporary depiction of the chapel, by Thomas Malton the Younger, see https://collections.britishart.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3637899
Constituent college of the University of Oxford, founded in 1249.
Late sixteenth-/early seventeenth-century inn in Dorchester-on-Thames; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1047829
Eighteenth-century hotel in Henley-on-Thames; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1047731
Late seventeenth-century hotel in Maidenhead; https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1303373
Used in reference to the former colonies of North America following the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776. See also North America and America.
Coaching inn on the High Street in Birmingham, demolished in the late 1950s/early 1960s. See here.
Hotel on New Street, Birmingham; see https://www.revolutionaryplayers.org.uk/view-of-lloyds-new-hotel-and-hen-and-chickens-inn-new-street-birmingham/
Cwrt-yr-Ala, mansion in Michaelston, just outside Cardiff; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/18502/details/cwrt-yr-alacourt-yr-alacwrt-yr-ala
Greyfriars was a thirteenth-century monastic settlement located to the east of Cardiff Castle; see http://www.monasticwales.org/site/53

placeName.geogName: St John the Baptist’s Church, Cardiff
placeName.note: St John the Baptist’s Church, Cardiff, largely rebuilt in the mid fifteenth century; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/301273/details/st-john-the-baptists-church-cardiff
Cathays House, built by the Earl of Bute after he acquired (by marriage) land in Cathays in the 1760s. The house was demolished in 1815.
Garth Mountain, north west of Cardiff.
Bridgewater Arms, inn near Pontypridd.

The Glamorganshire Canal. Constructed in the early 1790s, the canal ran for some 25 miles, connecting Cardiff and Merthyr Tydfil for industrial purposes; see http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/34425/details/glamorganshire-canal.

Cyfarthfa Ironworks, constructed in the mid-late eighteenth century and run by Richard Crawshay (1739-1810) from the 1780s onwards. By the mid-1790s, Cyfarthfa was the largest ironworks in Britain; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/34078/details/cyfarthfa-ironworks-merthyr-tydfil
Castle constructed in various stages from the eleventh century onwards; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/94876/details/abergavenny-castle.
Eighteenth-century inn in Brecon; see here
The building of Dyffryn Aled, Llansannan, Denbighshire, was begun in 1777. See here [accessed 19 June 2019].

Halston Hall in Shropshire was owned by Thomas Pennant's maternal family of Mytton from 1549. See here [accessed 24 June 2019]; and for the Pennant-Mytton connection, Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', p. 26.
Suffolk.
Seat of John Holland, who married Margaret, one of the six daughters of Robert Davies of Gwysane.

Southwark, London. Pennant's account of St. Saviour's Dock, which he suggests 'may be considered as the port of Southwark', is critical of its dimensions, arguing that deepening the dock would enable 'sloops and lesser vessels ... from different sea-ports' to make use of it for discharging cargo in the most cost-effective and practicable way possible. Of London (1790), p. 55.
Essex.

The oldest canal in London, linking the Thames at Limehouse Basin to the River Lee at Bromley-by-Bow, Limehouse Cut opened in 1770. A new cut made into the Regent's Canal's Limehouse Basin replaced the earlier lock to accommodate barges from contrary directions. See here [accessed 3 September 2019]; here [accessed 3 September 2019].
East End of London.
Its source in the Chiltern Hills, the River Lea flows through east London where it joins the Thames.
East London.
Mayfair, London.
Southwark, London.

Southwark, London. See 'The borough of Southwark: Introduction', in A History of the County of Surrey: Volume 4, ed. H E Malden (London, 1912), pp. 125–35. British History Online, here [accessed 4 September 2019].
South East London.
East London.
An area of Southwark, south of the Thames.
Dorset.

A spa complete with pump-room, medicinal waters and facilities for tea-drinking, established in the 1750s and achieving a fashionable status towards the end of the century. Mike Rendell, 'The rise and rise, and the decline and fall, of Bagnigge Wells', in 'Georgian Gentleman: The musings of Richard Hall 1729–1801', here [accessed 4 September 2019].
A prison in the Clerkenwell area, London.
John Keyse Sherwin operated from this address according to information on a publication dated 18 January 1789. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].
A district within the City of Westminster. For an etching and aquatint of John Street, Adelphi, by Thomas Malton the younger, dated 21 December 1795, see here [accessed 5 September 2019].
Kennington, South East London. William Owen [Pughe] lived at no. 40.
Parish church in the City of London.
George Street adjoins Hanover Square in Mayfair, London. Pennant stayed at no. 5 during the early 1790s.

The Welsh School was established in 1718 by the London-Welsh society, the Antient Britons. Admitting girls as well as boys from 1768, it eventually became 'The Welsh Girls' School'. It moved to a building on Gray's-Inn Lane in 1772. Jenkins and Ramage, <hi rend="italic">HHSC</hi>, p. 15.
Bloomsbury, London. Gray's Inn Lane has been known from the middle of the nineteenth century as Gray's Inn Road.

The Navy Office was based in Tower Hill, London, until 1786. By 1789 it had completed its move to a completely renovated Somerset House on the south side of the Strand. See here [accessed 24 September 2019].

On the south west coast of Anglesey. Aberffraw was the chief seat of the kings of Gwynedd during the early Middle Ages, its dominion stretching from the river Mawddach in the south to the river Conwy in the east when Gruffudd ap Cynan regained the kingdom in 1098. Davies, A History of Wales, p. 116.

A location in Flintshire, according to John Leland, The itinerary of John Leland the Antiquary (Oxford, 1710–12). Pennant writes in A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), I, p. 90, that 'we know of no such place in the county'.

St Chad's Church, Hanmer, dates from the twelfth century but was twice badly damaged by fire. Only its exterior walls are original. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/309700/details/st-chads-church-hanmer">here</ref> and <ref type="http" target="https://www.wrexham.gov.uk/english/leisure_tourism/open_church_network/st_chads.htm">here</ref> [both accessed 13 September 2019].

St Werburgh, Chester, was created under the leadership of Hugh I, earl of Chester, who in 1092 began the process of transforming a church of secular canons in the town into a Benedictine abbey. A. P. Baggs, Ann J. Kettle, S. J. Lander, A. T. Thacker and David Wardle, 'Houses of Benedictine monks: The abbey of Chester', in <hi rend="italic">A History of the County of Chester: Volume 3</hi>, ed. C. R. Elrington and B. E. Harris (London, 1980), pp. 132–46, in British History Online, <ref type="http" target="http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/ches/vol3/pp132-146">here</ref> [accessed 16 September 2019].
A hundred within Flintshire, known in Welsh as 'Tegeingl', from the Latin 'Deceangli'.

A township on the Welsh border, near Wrexham. The name is given in the Domesday Book in 1086, and the form 'Mereford' is recorded in 1662. See Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, 'Place-Names of Flintshire', p. 118 <ref type="http" target="https://www.cymdeithasenwaulleoedd.cymru/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Cronfa-Ddata-KLGF-Database-List-A.pdf">here</ref> [accessed 17 September 2019].
A cantref of the Kindgom of Powys.

For variant forms of the Flintshire name 'Hoseley', including that of 'Odesley' recorded in the Domesday Book (1086), see Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, 'Place-Names of Flintshire', pp. 96–7 here [accessed 17 September 2019].

Emral Hall and its surrounding gardens are located in Worthenbury, Flintshire. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/86647/details/emral-hall-garden-worthenbury">here</ref> [accessed 17 September 2019].
Halkyn Mountain or Mynydd Helygain, Flintshire, site of early mining for lead.

Moel Hiraddug, a hill and hill fort in the Clwydian range. For early variants of the name, including the form 'Rriaddig' noted c. 1550–62, see See Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, 'Place-Names of Flintshire', p. 122 <ref type="http" target="https://www.cymdeithasenwaulleoedd.cymru/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Cronfa-Ddata-KLGF-Database-List-A.pdf">here</ref>; see also <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/95092/details/moel-hiraddug-camp">here</ref> [both sites accessed 17 September 2019].

Gop Hill or, in Welsh, Coparleni, is a neolithic mound situated above Trelawnyd, Flintshire. For variant forms of the name including 'Coperlenid' recorded in George Owen's Pembrokeshire (1602), see Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, 'Place-Names of Flintshire', p. 74 here; and on the cairn, here [both accessed 17 September 2019].

A river which falls in a steep waterfall at Dyserth, Flintshire, before flowing into the River Clwyd. See <ref type="http" target="https://www.dailypost.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/stunning-welsh-waterfalls-you-not-12932281">here</ref> [accessed 17 September 2019].

The castle at Rhuthun, Denbighshire, was built from 1277, and more or less demolished during a Civil War siege in 1646. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/94739/details/ruthin-castle-ruthin">here</ref> [accessed 18 September 2019].

Llanasa, Flintshire. The parkland of the current Talacre Hall, developed during the nineteenth century, conceals an early post-medieval estate. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/36250/details/talacre-hall-talacre-abbey">here</ref> [accessed 18 September 2019].

Bodrhyddan Hall, Rhuddlan, Flintshire, was built mainly in 1696, but incorporates an earlier building. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/35670/details/bodrhyddan-hall-dyserth">here</ref> [accessed 18 September 2019].

Bretton Hall lies on the border of Flintshire and Cheshire. The original house was surrounded by a moat; a new house was built close to the site during the eighteenth century. See here, and here [both accessed 18 September 2019].
For the lordship of Fennes, see Willim Hanmer.
Village in Shropshire.
Village in Shropshire.
Church of All Saints, parish church in Baschurch, Shropshire, with late twelfth-century origins. See here
Late seventeenth-century country house in Baschurch, Shropshire, owned by the Hunt family. See <ref type="http" target="https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1055962">here</ref>

Ruthin School, Denbighshire, founded in the latter part of the thirteenth century, was granted a Royal Charter following its re-establishment in 1574 by Gabriel Goodman. See here [accessed 6 November 2019].
Traditionally part of Denbighshire.
Village COMPLETE NOTE
Seven-arched red sandstone bridge over the River Dee, on the outskirts of Chester, which dates from the late fourteenth century; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1375850
Located between Hawarden and Northrop, on the edge of Wepre Park.
Rhuallt Hill is hill situated on what is now the A55 coast road, north of Tremeirchion.
Hill between Abergele and Llanddulas on the north Wales coast; see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cefn_yr_Ogof

The River Conwy had to be crossed by boat until the suspension bridge over the river was built in 1826; see http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/271592/details/conway-ferry. For a contemporary depiction of the crossing, by Edward Pugh, see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Conway_Ferry_(1130889).jpg.
Late eighteenth-century villa, probably designed by Samuel Wyatt, overlooking the Conwy estuary; see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/3045/details/benarth-hallpenarth
St Cybi’s Church, Holyhead, parts of which date from the thirteenth century; see http://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/27500/details/st-cybis-church-holyhead
Unidentified broch in Strathaird, Skye.

During their long running feud with the Macdonalds, the Macleods of Dunvegan and Harris murdered up to four hundred people on the island of Eigg in the sixteenth century. Seeking retribution for the recent mistreatment of some of their clansmen by the Macdonalds, a party of Macleods landed on Eigg, causing the inhabitants of the island to take refuge in a cave. On discovering the hiding place, they blocked the entrance to the cave and started a fire, suffocating those inside. Tourists including Hugh Miller and Walter Scott later visited the cave, and large numbers of bones were discovered there as recently as 2016.
Riverside hotel in Llangollen, renamed the Royal Hotel in the 1830s; See here.
A small village with a notable waterfall on the Mawddach estuary road between Dolgellau and Barmouth. The old road to Barmouth headed up into the hills from here.
The Ellesmere Canal, a huge engineering project that connected the Dee Valley and Shropshire, was constructed in the 1790s and first years of the 1800s. See here.
Village in Montgomeryshire, Powys.

Coaching Inn situated next-door to the better-known Lion on Wyle Cop, Shrewsbury. In 1816 Thomas J. Howells noted that 'extensive and good accommodations for travellers and is well frequented'. (The Stranger in Shrewsbury, 1816). Not to be confused with the Raven Hotel on Castle Street.

The Talbot Inn, Shrewsbury, was built in Market Street in 1775 by the Oteley family of Pitchford Hall. (See Barrie Stuart Trinder, The Industrial Archaeology of Shropshire, 1996). In 1816 Thomas J. Howell noted ' Extensive premises with requisite accommodations Coaches run from this house similarly to those from the Lion'. (The Stranger in Shrewsbury).

Located in Princess Street, and described as 'a travellers' inn'. Thomas J. Howell, The Stranger in Shrewsbury, or, an Historical and Descriptive View of Shrewsbury and its Environs (Shrewsbury, 1816).
Mountain pass into Dyffryn Nantlle, Snowdonia.
Unidentified headland on south of Ardnamurchan peninsula. Possibly a (mis)translation from Gaelic.

Afon Mawddach (the River Mawddach) flows from Dolgellau to debouch at Barmouth (in Welsh 'Abermaw', now Y Bermo); 'Mawdd' and 'Maw' are earlier forms of the river-name. The Mawddach Estuary was and is noted for its beauty, and in the C18th there was considerable ship-building activity here. See the sketch by John Sell Cotman: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Google_Art_Project_works_by_John_Sell_Cotman#/media/File:John_Sell_Cotman_-_Cader_Idris_from_the_Mawddach_Estuary_above_Barmouth_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg
An ancient commote name, used in modern times for the region around Corwen. For a 1793 illustration of the valley just outside Corwen, by Thomas Walmsley, see here.
Village above Talsarnau on the old road to Tan-y-Bwlch

A mansion first recorded in the C14th; owned in the C18th-C19th by the Nanney-Wynn family
https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/28593/details/maes-y-neuadd
The valley of the River Artro, north of Barmouth, Meirionydd, which leads up to Cwmbychan in the Rhinog mountains.

The village of Coalbrookdale in Shropshire became a major centre for industry, especially iron production, in the eighteenth century. For a contemporary depiction of one of its furnaces, by Edward Dayes, see here.
The marshy area below Harlech, Meirionydd. Tŷ Gwyn y Gamlas was a ferry embarkation point for travellers crossing the Traeth Mawr and Traeth Bach. See here.
Vaynol Hall is a country estate near Felinheli, Caernarfon;see here.
A remote mountain pass in the Rhinogydd in Meirionydd. Described by Thomas Pennant in Tours in Wales, II (1784) 122.

Pennant describes Carreg y Klommenod. (The Rock of the Pigeons: modern spelling: 'colommenod', doves or pigeons) in Tours in Wales, II (1784) 122, as he passes through Bwlch Drws Ardudwy in the Rhinog mountains, Meirionydd.

Lake south of Dolgellau, at the foot of Cadair Idris. Three large rocks by the lake are supposed to be three grains or pieces of gravel which the giant Idris found in his shoe and flung away. For a contemporary picture by S.H. Grimm see: https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/20298.
A river which runs from Aran Benllyn into the Mawddach near Dolgellau,
A village south of Llanwuchllyn, on the road between Dolgellau and Bala.
Village by Bala Lake (Llyn Tegid). The Methodist Minister Thomas Charles (1755-1814) is buried in the churchyard there.
A former coaching Inn at Rhydymain on the road between Dolgellau and Bala. During the C18th it was the meeting place of a local gentry society of 'Lloerigion' (The Hell Fire Club).

The Royal Hotel in Caernarfon was built around 1794, when it was known as the Uxbridge Arms. See <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/16817/details/royal-hotel-north-road-and-bangor-road-uxbridge-arms-formerly-celtic-royal-hotel "<here</ref>.
Eighteenth-century hotel named after the Corwen-linked Welsh leader Owain Glyndŵr; see here and here.
The Crown Hotel in Denbigh was remodelled in the nineteenth century; see <ref target="http://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/27090/details/crown-hotel-5-crown-square-denbigh" type="http">here</ref>.
A fortification above the River Dee near Corwen, close to the remains of a moated manor; thought to have been in the possession of Owain Glyndwr from the early C15th. See here.
A tributary of the River Dee, rising in the Berwyn mountains.
Village in Shropshire north of River Severn, formerly on the main coach road into north Wales (A5)
An inn at Nesscliffe in Shropshire
Village between Betws-y-Coed and Cerrig y Drudion; the chapel was built in 1766.
Inn at Bangor.
The Holywell or Holway Water Level was built in the 1770s mainly to carry lead ore and mine workers to and from lead mines nearby.
Seventeenth-century coaching inn in Denbigh; see here.
Early eighteenth-century inn in Ruthin, later renamed the Castle Hotel; see here.

Now demolished, the Harp Inn stood on the High Street in Conwy. John Varley's 1809 painting is held in the National Library of Wales; see here. The landlord of this inn apparently drowned in the river, at some point after 1797.
The landlord of the Royal Hotel, Chester in 1822 was M. Willoughby, hence Anne Lister's description of it in her tour of Wales as 'Willoughby's'. See here.
, 'A round, smooth, stupendous mountain covered with smooth green turf' (Pennant). A mountain in Snowdonia, east of Caernarfon; it forms one side of the Gwyrfai valley.
Gateway on the east side of Caernarfon Castle; for a modern photograph, see here.
River which flows into the Menai Straits at Caernarfon.
Village adjoining the old A5 road, between Corwen and Betws-y-Coed.
The C17th Deanery at Bangor is incorporated into a later C19th building. https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/26393/details/the-deanery
Now known as Y Maes or Castle Square.
Village in the Conwy Valley, on the edge of Snowdonia. The River Llugwy runs alongside the village and features in many contemporary images of it; see, for example, here.
Bridge over the River Llugwy in Betws-y-Coed, completed in 1815 by Thomas Telford as part of his work on the A5 route. For a contemporary illustration of the bridge, see here.
The Britannia Copper Mine was located on the south side of Snowdon, where copper was extracted from at least the eighteenth century; see here.
Mountain pass to the east of Snowdon. For a contemporary depiction of its dramatic landscape, see here.
Llyn Gwynant is a lake to the south-east of Snowdon. For an 1830s view of the lake, by Samuel Palmer, see here.
Vaynol Arms, inn (formerly a farmhouse) in Nant Peris, near Llanberis in Snowdonia. For a photograph of the inn dating from the 1950s, see here.
Bridge across the Seiont river on the road from Caernarfon to Llanberis (now A4086)
Bridge across the Seiont river, just outside Caernarfon, on Llanbeblig Road, heading towards Beddgelert (now A4085)
Turnpike bridge on the road to Pwllheli from Caernarfon.
Small village east of Caernarfon, between Llanberis and Llanrug.
Small estate near Caernarfon, on the River Seiont, owned in the late C18th by Thomas Lloyd of Shrewsbury. http://www.heneb.co.uk/hlc/caernarfon-nantlle/caer29.html
Late fifteenth-century bridge over the River Llugwy at Betws-y-Coed; see here. For a selection of contemporary images of the bridge, see here.
Small town on the north Wales coast, near Conwy.
Inn at Conwy.
Rhaeadr Fawr, known in English as Aber Falls, is a waterfall near Abergwyngregyn, Gwynedd. For a contemporary depiction of the falls, see here.
Inn near the Nant Ffrancon pass in Snowdonia.
Llyn Ogwen is a lake to the north-east of Snowdon. For a contemporary engraving depicting the lake, see here.
Village between Bangor and Tal-y-Bont in Gwynedd.
Inn opposite Bangor Cathedral.
Hotel in Bangor built in 1799 by Benjamin Wyatt, of which only the portico now remains; see here.

A wooded hillock just outside Beddgelert. For a contemporary depiction, by Moses Griffith, see <ref type="http" target="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:DV_27_No.47.Dinas_Emrys.png">here</ref).
Village near Blaenau Ffestiniog in Gwynedd.
Glyder Fawr is a peak to the north-east of Snowdon. For a series of recent photographs of this peak, which Pennant memorably described in the second volume of his Tour, see here.
TO BE COMPLETED
TO BE COMPLETED
St Twrog's Church, Maentwrog, a medieval church rebuilt in the early nineteenth century; see here.
Roadside inn in the village of Drws y Nant, between Dolgellau and Bala.
Hotel in Dolgellau, demolished in the 1920s.
Nineteenth-century coaching inn at Dolgellau. For a recent photograph, see here.
Eighteenth-century coaching inn at Bala. For a nineteenth-century photograph, see here.
The Bull's Head, a seventeenth-century coaching inn at Bala; for a recent photograph, see here.
River rising near Rhyd-Ddu at the foot of Snowdon; it passes through Llyn Cwellyn and the villages of Betws Garmon and Waunfawr and joins the Menai west of Caernarfon.
Mountain in the Gwyrfai Valley in Snowdonia.
Bridge over the Gwyrfai river, Betws Garmon, Snowdonia.
A mill on the Gwyrfai above Betws Garmon, depicted in an early C19th engraving here: https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/22006
A tributary of the Glaslyn which rises on the south-western flank of Snowdon and descends to Beddgelert.

Valley in Snowdonia which developed in the C19th as a centre for slate quarrying. Depicted before industrialization in Richard Wilson's 'Snowdon from Llyn Nantlle (1765/66): https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Richard_Wilson_-_Snowdon_from_Llyn_Nantlle_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg
Village between Blaenau Ffestiniog and Betws-y-Coed yn north Wales, noted for its striking C13th castle.

Jutting headland near Old Colwyn. Pennant notes ‘In my memory the traveller went along a narrow path cut on its front, like the road on Penmaen Mawr, but infinitely more terrible and dangerous; a fine coach-road has of late been formed far behind this precipice'. Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), II, p. 334.
Village on the north Wales coast, near Abergele.
Village near Abergele onthe north coast of Wales. It is close to the Kinmel estate.

C18th coaching inn at Llanrhaeadr near Denbigh. In 1797 it apparently bore a sign with the following verse:
Within this place there is a vault Where such good liquor’s fix’d You’ll say that water, hops and malt Were never better mix’d.
Mountain pass in the Clwydian Range in north-east Wales, between Moel Famau (to the north) and Foel Fenlli (to the south) on a small road between Tafarn-y-Gelyn and Llanbedr-Dyffryn-Clwyd.
The highest hill in the Clwydian range. A tower was builit on its summit to celebrate the golden jubilee of George III in 1810.
Village on the eastern slopes of the Clwydian Range, Denbighshire, in the upper Alyn valley.
The old prison at Chester was redesigned by Thomas Harrison and completed in 1792.
Notorious stretch of poor road in Denbighshire, now a section of the A549 between Lane End and Dobs Hill.

An area of Chester near the Exchange. Described in 1784 as 'a spacious area called the Pentise, where the two principal streets intersect each other'. G.A. Walpoole The New British Traveller; Or, A Complete Modern Universal Display of Great Britain. (London, 1784)
Village in Cheshire, famous for legend of the 'headless woman.'
Village in Cheshire.
Large village with a market in Cheshire.

A Grade I listed C14th church with substantial C19th restoration. For an image by George Ormerod from 1819 see : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Church,_Nantwich#/media/File:Nantwich_parish_church_-_Ormerod.jpg

The Abbey Church of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, Shrewsbury was founded in 1083 as a Benedictine monastery by Roger de Montgomery, Earl of Shrewsbury. In 1137/38 the then prior, Robert of Shrewsbury, organized the translation of the relics of St Winifred from Gwytherin in north Wales to the Abbey, and wrote a Life of the saint soon afterwards.
Village on the road between Bangor and Conwy; access point for the waterfall, Rhaeadr Fawr /Aber Falls, further up the valley, where the Afon Goch falls some 120 feet.

Village on Anglesey close to the Menai Straits. Home of the C18th antiquarian Henry Rowlands, who is buried in the graveyard of St Edwen's Church. Rowlands' Mona Antiqua Restaurata (1723) was an inspiration to tourists looking for 'Druidic' landscapes.
Church at Llanedwen, extensively rebuilt in the C19th. The antiquarian Henry Rowlands (1655-1723) is buried there.
A prehistoric burial mound still partially covered in earth and trees on the Plas Newydd estate, Anglesey. See here.
Two megalithic chambers from a Neolithic barrow in Plas Newydd Park; both chambers have their capstones. For a Romantic-period image see Thomas Pennant's Extra-Illustrated Tours in Wales:
Now famous among tourists for the extended form of its name (Llanfair­pwllgwyngyll­gogery­chwyrn­drobwll­llan­tysilio­gogo­goch); a village on the Menai Straits, Anglesey, opposite Bangor.
Precipitous mountain ridge (or arete) of 3,028 ft forming one of the ascents of Snowdon/ yr Wyddfa. The name means Red Ridge.
Second highest peak in Wales, part of the Snowdon massif.
Valley in Snowdonia leading to Capel Curig.
Small market town in Montgomeryshire, Powys.
Church in the village of Llwndecwyn, Gwynedd, of medieval origins. See here.
Medieval church at Llanycil, a village adjoining Llyn Tegid (Bala Lake). See here.

Small village in the hills on the old mountain road between between Beddgelert and Tan-y-Bwlch, overlooking Traeth Mawr and Traeth Bach. For an early sketch by Robert Price (1717-1761; father of Uvedale Price) who toured north Wales in 1759 with Benjamin Stillingfleet, see : https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:A_Tour_in_Wales_by_Thomas_Pennant#/media/File:Caynant,_Llanvrothen_by_Robert_Price_esq.jpg,

Before the embankment across the Glaslyn estuary, St Brothen's was close to the shore, near the dangerous tidal crossing at Traeth Mawr. It is a Grade I listed building, dating from the C13th. See https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/43860/details/st-brothens-church-llanfrothen
River that has its source in the slopes of Snowdon, flowing through Beddgelert and the rocky gorge of the Pass of Aberglaslyn, before flowing out into Tremadog Bay.
Waterfall south of Llan Ffestiniog, Gwynedd.

An inn on the old drovers road at Llandegla-yn-Ial, between Wrexham and Ruthin. In 1800 Catherine Hutton noted 'It is the Cross Foxes, but whoever seeks it by that token will seek in vain, for the Foxes, instead of giving intelligence at the door, are placed over the parlour chimney, and the house is generally known by the name of Tavarn Dowyrch'. In 1854 when George Borrow visited it was Tafarn Dywyrch ('tywarchen' is a sod of earth, and may refer to earlier roof). When Hutton visited it was run by a 'female Falstaff, Mrs Davies'.
Inn at Abergele, run in 1800 by Mr and Mrs Davies.

Village on the Llŷn Peninsula in Gwynedd, and site of the medieval church of St Beuno, an important stop for pilgrims heading for Bardsey Island. For a view by Moses Griffith see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Clynnog_by_Moses_Griffith_1782.jpg.
Market town on the Llŷn Peninsula.
Village about three miles south of Caernarfon in Gwynedd.
Village south of Caernarfon, at the northerly entrance to the Llŷn Peninsula. Its church is dedicated to St Twrog, also patron of Maentwrog in Meirionydd.
Scene of Macpherson's Ossianic poem, 'Comala'.
Known as Macduff after 1783.
Unknown location near Turriff, Aberdeenshire. Possibly misspelled by the author, Jacob Pattison.
Single barrel-vault stone bridge crossing Afon Aber in the valley leading to the Aber Falls, Caernarfonshire. It was on the route of an old drovers road.
Yr Eifl (often called the Rivals in English) is a three-peaked chain of mountains on the north coast of the Llŷn Peninsula in Gwynedd: the peaks are Tre'r Ceiri, Garn Ganol and Garn Fôr.
Gyrn Goch and Gyrn Ddu are hills on the Llŷn Peninsula just south of Clynnog Fawr.
A small village on Anglesey, close to Beaumaris and the Menai Strait. Llywelyn the Great built a Francisan monastery here in 1237 to house the body of his wife Joan.
Highest mountain in the Carneddau range in Snowdonia (3491 ft).
Part of the Carneddau range in Snowdonia; adjacent to Carnedd Llywelyn, it is the third highest peak in Wales. (3425 ft)
A distinctive peak in the Snowdonia range, with jagged, scalloped edges; part of the Glyderau. (3010 ft)
The second highest mountain in the Glyder range in Snowdonia (3261 ft)
Northernmost mountain peak of the Glyderau, Snowdonia
Peak in the Glyderau range, just north of Llyn Padarn and Llanberis.
A peak in the Nantlle ridge, Caernarfonshire, it sits between the villages of Nantlle and Carmel
Steep and narrow valley from Capel Curig to Llyn Ogwen in Snowdonia.

A dramatic corrie with a lake, in the Glyderau range, noted for its rare alpine plants. It was explored in 1798 by William Bingley, and later by Charles Darwin. Its natural history was extensively catalogued by the quarryman and botanist Evan Roberts (1901-1991).
River in Snowdonia, draining from Llyn Idwal, Cwm Idwal, to join the river Ogwen.
Now known as the church of St Julitta. See http://www.stjulittas.org/english/about.html#History
Village near Caernarfon, in north-west Wales.
One of the Moelwynion group of mountains, which extends from Porthmadog to Moel Siabod across central Snowdonia.
Tallest of the Moelwynions (2,861 ft), it overlooks Betws-y-Coed and Capel Curig.
River in Snowdonia which runs below Dolwyddelan and joins the river Conwy at Betws-y-Coed.
Stone bridge across the Lledr river near Betws y Coed: https://library.nga.gov/permalink/01NGA_INST/1s1dit0/alma994127256904896
Single arch stone bridge over the river Conwy, east of Betws-y-Coed : https://www.coflein.gov.uk/en/site/23810/details/pont-rhydlanfair
Village near Oswestry, with a castle
Late eighteenth-century inn in Whittington, near Oswestry; see https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1178295
River in mid-Wales that flows out into Cardigan Bay at Aberdyfi. Its estuary marks the boundary between the counties of Gwynedd and Ceredigion.
River in mid-Wales, which flows into the Dyfi near Mallwyd.
Coastal town located in the south of Gwynedd.
Village on the north side of the Dyfi estuary, located in the south of Gwynedd.
https://canmore.org.uk/site/52586/edinburgh-water-of-leith-st-bernards-well

placeName.geogName: Grave Of Bessie Bell and Mary Gray
placeName.addName: graves of Bessy Bell and Mary Gray

placeName.note: Area of saltmarshes and mudflats mainly on the Flintshire side of the Dee Estuary, just outside Chester. The Wales-England border runs through Saltney; see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/414337/details/saltney

The Beechwood Park estate in Hertfordshire was the home of Sir John Saunders Sebright, sixth baronet (1725–94) from 1761, and housed a collection of Edward Lhuyd's manuscripts, purchased by his predecessor Sir Thomas Sebright, fourth baronet (1692–1736) in 1715. See Eiluned Rees and Gwyn Walters, 'The dispersion of the manuscripts of Edward Lhuyd', in Welsh History Review, vol. 7, part 2 (1974), 148–78; and here [accessed 10 July 2020].

For a reference among Thomas Pennant's papers to the inn known as the Antelope or Bell and Antelope in Holywell, see Warwickshire County Record Office, CR 2017/TP597/1-15, which includes an eighteenth-century playbill on silk for performances of plays at the inn; <ref type="http" target="https://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/b3f79e99-8160-4977-8467-74e1d1c321b4">here</ref> [accessed 15 July 2020].

For Llanddwyn Island, a narrow promontory on Llanddwyn beach near Newborough in south-west Anglesey, see <ref type="http" target=" https://www.anglesey-history.co.uk/places/llanddwyn/">here</ref>[accessed 15 July 2020].
West Indies island.

A monolithic cross at Whitford, Flintshire, dating from c. 1000AD. here [accessed 15 July 2020]. For Pennant's description of it, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784). pp. 12–13, and for Moses Griffith's illustration, engraved by Peter Mazell, ibid., frontispiece.
Late medieval church in Dyserth, Flintshire. See here [accessed 15 July 2020].
Village and parish in North Yorkshire.
Seaside resort in present day borough of Conwy County, north Wales.

Rhos Fynach, Rhos-on-sea, Denbighshire. This cottage, with features dating as far back as the fifteenth century is thought to have been the grange of Maenan Abbey. In his notice of 'Rhos Vynach, or the Marsh of the Monks, having been the property of Conwy abbey', Pennant describes a weir, its yield of fish shared between the bishop and the vicar of nearby Llandrillo every tenth tide. See <hi rend="italic">A tour in Wales</hi> (2nd edn., 1784), p. 334; <ref type="http" target="adhttps://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/269/details/rhos-fynach-rhos-on-seadress">here</ref>; and <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/303159/details/r0yal-fishing-weir-fish-trap-rhos-fynach ">here</ref> [accessed 16 July 2020].

Plas Glynllifon is a mansion house in Llandwrog, Gwynedd. The house that would have been encountered by travellers in our period was the second built on this site, destroyed by fire and subsequently rebuilt around the mid-nineteenth century, as the seat of the Wynn family (Sir Thomas John Wynn became the 1st Lord Newborough in 1776). See https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/26526/details/glynllifon-mansion-llandwrog.

Pennant notes the fertile tract between Prestatyn and Rhuddlan, interrupted only by the marsh. The latter is 'Morfa Rhuddlan', situated in the community of Kinmel Bay and Towyn in the old county of Denbighshire, and allegedly the site of the battle of Rhuddlan Marsh in 795AD. See Pennant, <hi rend="italic">A tour in Wales</hi> (2nd edn. 1784), II, p. 5; and <ref type="http" target="https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/404808/details/rhuddlan-marsh-alleged-site-of-battle-in-795-a-d-morfa-rhuddlan-towyn">here</ref> [accessed 16 July 2020].

The New Inn at Clynnog was built in the early seventeenth century; see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/26044/details/bod-fasarnnew-inn-clynnog. For a striking image of the inn, see https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/14758.
Fifteenth-century church on the site of a seventh-century monastery, in Clynnog, Gwynedd; see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/43695/details/st-beunos-chapel
The channel separating the islands of Ireland and Britain.
﻿On Ynys Cybi (Holy Island), Anglesey.

The Pillar of Eliseg, situated near Valle Crucis abbey, Denbighshire, was erected in the ninth century in commemoration of Eliseg (or Elisedd) by his great-grandson Cyngen. The inscription upon it was recorded in 1696 by Edward Lhuyd. See Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 34–5, 41; and here [accessed 24 September 2020].
A street off Oxford Street. See <ref type="http" target="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vere_Street,_Marylebone">here</ref> [accessed 25 September 2020].
Near Corwen, Denbighshire.
London.
Former county town of Flintshire, on the estuary of the River Dee.

Worthenbury in Flintshire was noted by John Leland in his <hi rend="italic">Itinerary</hi>, and features as a place name in the Domesday book of 1086 and subsequent texts under variant forms. See Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, <hi rend="italic">Place-names of Flintshire: List A</hi> (n.p., n.d.), pp. 211–12, <ref type="http" target="https://www.cymdeithasenwaulleoedd.cymru/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Cronfa-Ddata-KLGF-Database-List-A.pdf">here</ref> [accessed 29 September 2020].
For Bangor Is-Coed, Flintshire, see Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, Place-names of Flintshire: List A (n.p., n.d.), pp. 11–12, here [accessed 29 September 2020].
Located in Shropshire, near the border with Wales.
Denbighshire.
Denbighshire.

Near Mold, Flintshire. For variant forms of the name dating from 1202, see Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, Place-names of Flintshire: List A (n.p., n.d.), pp. 40–41, here [accessed 29 September 2020].

Flintshire. For variant forms of the name, dating from its first attestation in the Domesday Book in 1086, see Hywel Wyn Owen and Ken Lloyd Gruffydd, <hi rend="italic">Place-names of Flintshire: List A</hi> (n.p., n.d.), pp. 213–14, <ref type="http" target="https://www.cymdeithasenwaulleoedd.cymru/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Cronfa-Ddata-KLGF-Database-List-A.pdf">here</ref> [accessed 29 September 2020].
Pembrokeshire.
Badminton in Somerset was the home of the dukes of Beaufort. See <ref type="http" target="https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1320832">here</ref> [accessed 30 September 2020].
